    A. Data Discovery and Retrieval B. Dataset Integration

B. Dataset Integration

Source: vignettes/b_integration.Rmd
b_integration.Rmd

Introduction

This work flow emulates ‘Integrating multi-dataset slices of data’ cellxgene-census tutorial, although the integtation path uses Bioconductor packages. Start by loading the CxGcensus and SingleCellExperiment packages.

library(CxGcensus)
library(SingleCellExperiment)

Datasets and observations

Select the ‘Tabula Muris Sensis’ collection with datasets containing ‘liver’ in their title.

liver <-
    datasets() |>
    dplyr::filter(
        collection_name == "Tabula Muris Senis",
        grepl("liver", dataset_title, ignore.case = TRUE)
    )
liver
#> # A tibble: 2 × 8
#>   soma_joinid collection_id            collection_name collection_doi dataset_id
#>         <int> <chr>                    <chr>           <chr>          <chr>     
#> 1         494 0b9d8a04-bb9d-44da-aa27… Tabula Muris S… 10.1038/s4158… 4546e757-…
#> 2         516 0b9d8a04-bb9d-44da-aa27… Tabula Muris S… 10.1038/s4158… 6202a243-…
#> # ℹ 3 more variables: dataset_title <chr>, dataset_h5ad_path <chr>,
#> #   dataset_total_cell_count <int>

Retrieve the observations (cells) from these datasets.

dataset_ids <- pull(liver, dataset_id)
observations <- 
    observation_data("mus_musculus") |>
    dplyr::filter(dataset_id %in% dataset_ids) |>
    dplyr::collect()

Summarize observations by assay. There are two datasets, one is 10x Genomics the other Smart-seq2. Each dataset consists of several male and female donors of various developmental stage.

observations |>
    dplyr::count(dataset_id, assay)
#> # A tibble: 2 × 3
#>   dataset_id                           assay          n
#>   <chr>                                <chr>      <int>
#> 1 4546e757-34d0-4d17-be06-538318925fcd Smart-seq2  2859
#> 2 6202a243-b713-4e12-9ced-c387f8483dea 10x 3' v2   7294
observations |>
    dplyr::count(dataset_id, donor_id, sex, development_stage)
#> # A tibble: 21 × 5
#>    dataset_id                           donor_id sex    development_stage      n
#>    <chr>                                <chr>    <chr>  <chr>              <int>
#>  1 4546e757-34d0-4d17-be06-538318925fcd 18_45_M  male   18 month-old stage   275
#>  2 4546e757-34d0-4d17-be06-538318925fcd 18_46_F  female 18 month-old stage   533
#>  3 4546e757-34d0-4d17-be06-538318925fcd 18_53_M  male   18 month-old stage   372
#>  4 4546e757-34d0-4d17-be06-538318925fcd 24_58_M  male   20 month-old stag…   508
#>  5 4546e757-34d0-4d17-be06-538318925fcd 24_59_M  male   20 month-old stag…   440
#>  6 4546e757-34d0-4d17-be06-538318925fcd 3_11_M   male   3 month-old stage    420
#>  7 4546e757-34d0-4d17-be06-538318925fcd 3_56_F   female 3 month-old stage     82
#>  8 4546e757-34d0-4d17-be06-538318925fcd 3_57_F   female 3 month-old stage     79
#>  9 4546e757-34d0-4d17-be06-538318925fcd 3_9_M    male   3 month-old stage    150
#> 10 6202a243-b713-4e12-9ced-c387f8483dea 1-M-62   male   4 weeks              471
#> # ℹ 11 more rows

Retrieve all observations to a SingleCellExperiment. Add feature_id (i.e., Ensembl gene identifiers) as row names for downstream analysis.

sce <- single_cell_experiment(
    "mus_musculus", feature_data("mus_musculus"), observations
)
rownames(sce) <- rowData(sce)$feature_id
sce

Single dataset processing

We deviate from the cellxgene-census tutorial by performing preliminary steps on each data set.

We will do prelminary QC, normalization, variance modeling and dimensionality reduction on each dataset separately, Following Chapter 1 of the ‘Multisample’ section of Orchestrating Single Cell Analysis with Bioconductor. We’ll use the following packages

library(scater)
library(scran)
library(BiocSingular)

Start by creating separate Smart-seq2 and 10x SingleCellExperiments.

smartseq <- sce[, sce$assay == "Smart-seq2"]
tenx <- sce[, sce$assay != "Smart-seq2"]

Smart-seq2 mRNA represents the entire expressed protien, so longer genes inherently have more mRNA. Try to correct for this by dividing read counts by gene length. We set the metadata() of the Smart-seq2 dataset to an empty list, so that the metadata is not duplicated when the two datasets are combined at a later stage.

x <- counts(smartseq, withDimnames = FALSE)
x <- t( t(x) / rowData(smartseq)$feature_length )
counts(smartseq, withDimnames = FALSE) <- x
metadata(smartseq) <- list()

The following code chunk, from Chapter 1, performs each step on the Smart-seq2 and 10x datasets.

## A list of SingleCellExperiments
all.sce <- list(smartseq = smartseq, tenx = tenx)

## QC -- skip currently; no MT gene expression

## Normalization -- scater
all.sce <- lapply(all.sce, logNormCounts)

## Variance modelling -- scran
all.dec <- lapply(all.sce, modelGeneVar)
all.hvgs <- lapply(all.dec, getTopHVGs, prop=0.1)

## Dimensionality reduction -- BiocSingular
set.seed(10000)
all.sce <- Map(
    runPCA, x = all.sce, subset_row = all.hvgs, 
    MoreArgs = list(ncomponents = 25L, BSPARAM = RandomParam())
)

set.seed(100000)
all.sce <- lapply(all.sce, runTSNE, dimred = "PCA")

set.seed(1000000)
all.sce <- lapply(all.sce, runUMAP, dimred = "PCA")

## Clustering
for (n in names(all.sce)) {
    g <- buildSNNGraph(all.sce[[n]], k=10, use.dimred='PCA')
    clust <- igraph::cluster_walktrap(g)$membership
    colLabels(all.sce[[n]])  <- factor(clust)
}

Bind the resulting objects together

sce <- do.call("cbind", all.sce)

Dataset integration

We will use the batchelor package for dataset integration.

library(batchelor)

Following Chapter 1, quickCorrect() implements a workflow for dataset integration that includes identifying shared features, scaling batches to account for differences in sequencing depth, computation of log-normalized expression values, and identification of highly variable genes. Data integration uses mutual nearest neighbor (MNN) correction.

## batchelor
quick.corrected <- quickCorrect(
    all.sce[[1]], all.sce[[2]],
    precomputed = all.dec,
    PARAM = FastMnnParam(BSPARAM=BiocSingular::RandomParam())
)

quick.sce <- quick.corrected$corrected
## include colData from original sce
colData(quick.sce) <- cbind(colData(sce), colData(quick.sce))
quick.sce$batch <- factor(quick.sce$batch)
quick.sce

Visualize the final result in an interactive UMAP using plotUMAP() and the plotly package; to WebGL() makes the plot interactive even for 100’s of thousands of cells…

## scater
set.seed(00101010)
quick.sce <- runTSNE(quick.sce, dimred = "corrected")
quick.sce <- runUMAP(quick.sce, dimred = "corrected")

plotUMAP(quick.sce, colour_by="cell_type") |>
    plotly::ggplotly() |>
    plotly::toWebGL()
